Traumatic: Transmural disruption False lumen formation Adventitial hemorrhage Rupture Risk Stratification Morphological Criteria: Size >7mm: high risk Aspect ratio >1.6 Daughter sac presence Wall irregularity Hemodynamic Factors: Systolic BP >140 mmHg Flow pattern alterations Intrasaccular pressure gradients Genetic Markers: Collagen deficiency Elastic fiber abnormalities Matrix metalloproteinase polymorphisms Clinical Manifestations Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Hunt-Hess grading scale correlation Fisher scale for CT findings Modified Rankin Scale outcomes Mass Effect: Cranial nerve compression syndromes Brainstem compression sequelae Hydrocephalus development Thromboembolic Events: Watershed infarction patterns Perforator occlusion syndromes Distal embolization phenomena Endothelial injury due to HTN (Option A) while hypertension can exacerbate aneurysm formation and increase rupture risk, it is not the primary underlying cause of berry aneurysms. Hypertension acts as a contributing factor rather than the initiating defect. Endothelial layer defect (Option C) although the endothelium can be involved in aneurysm progression, the primary defect occurs in the internal elastic lamina rather than the endothelial layer. The endothelial dysfunction is usually secondary to the underlying structural abnormality. Adventitia defect (Option D) the adventitial layer is the outer layer of blood vessels and is not the primary site of berry aneurysm formation. The key pathology begins in the internal elastic lamina and medial layer of the vessel wall. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page: 3353-3355 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557480/

questions.question: A 16 year old girl, who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice?

options.A: Stop the treatment and follow up
options.B: Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment

questions.explanation: recommended approach in this scenario is to continue treatment for another 2 years. The duration of seizure freedom required before considering discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs varies, but typically 2-5 years of seizure freedom is considered an appropriate period. Incorrect Option: Option a. Stop the treatment and follow up: This option is incorrect. The 16-year-old girl has been seizure-free for 6 months, but it does not necessarily mean that she can safely stop the treatment altogether. Stopping the treatment abruptly can increase the risk of seizure recurrence. Option b. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This option is incorrect. While the girl has been seizure-free for 6 months, it is generally recommended to continue treatment for a longer period before considering tapering and stopping the antiepileptic drug. Gradual tapering of the drug under medical supervision may be considered later, but not at this stage. Option d. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This option is incorrect. Lifelong treatment with antiepileptic drugs is not necessary in all cases. If the girl remains seizure-free for a prolonged period (usually 2-5 years), there may be an opportunity to gradually taper and discontinue the medication under medical supervision. Reference: .

questions.question: A child is brought with a 2-week history of not feeding well and excessive irritability. History of TB for sister is present and is taking treatment for it. In workup, LP was performed. Which of the following is likely to be found in CSF?

options.A: Lymphocytosis, low sugar, and high protein
options.B: Lymphocytosis, high sugar, and high protein
options.C: Neutrophils, low sugar and low protein
options.D: Neutrophils, low sugar and high protein

questions.explanation: in the CSF of a child with a suspected tuberculous meningitis, which is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The history of TB in the sister raises the suspicion of an infectious etiology. Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reveals a high leukocyte count (up to 1000/ µ L), usually with a predominance of lymphocytes but sometimes with a predominance of neutrophils in the early stage; a protein content of 1–8 g/L (100–800 mg/dL); and a low glucose concentration. Incorrect Options: Option B - Lymphocytosis, high sugar and high protein: While lymphocytosis and high protein levels are expected in a CNS infection, high sugar levels (hyperglycorrhachia) are not typical. Viruses and certain bacteria tend to decrease CSF glucose levels due to increased consumption. Therefore, this option is less likely. Option C - Neutrophils, low sugar, and low protein: Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell associated with bacterial infections. The combination of low sugar and low protein levels is not characteristic of most CNS infections, as infections typically lead to increased protein levels due to the inflammatory response. This pattern is not consistent with the clinical presentation and history provided. Option D - Neutrophils, low sugar, and high protein: While neutrophils could be present in the CSF in cases of acute bacterial meningitis, the combination of low sugar and high protein levels is not typical. Acute bacterial infections tend to lower CSF glucose levels due to consumption, but they also lead to an increase in protein levels. This option does not match the expected pattern for the given clinical scenario.

questions.question: In hypoglossal nerve injury , which of the following is seen?

options.A: Tongue deviation to the contralateral side
options.B: Tongue deviation to the same side

questions.explanation: nerve that controls the movement of the tongue. When the hypoglossal nerve is injured, tongue deviation to the same side as the injury is the most common symptom. This is because the muscles on the affected side of the tongue become weak or paralyzed while the muscles on the unaffected side remain functional. Incorrect Options: Option A - Tongue deviation to the contralateral side: Tongue deviation to the contralateral side is incorrect as it suggests that the tongue would move towards the opposite side of the injury. However, this is not a typical presentation of hypoglossal nerve injury. Option C - Falling of the tongue: Falling of the tongue is also incorrect, as this is a nonspecific symptom that could occur due to various reasons, including weakness or paralysis of the tongue muscles. Option D - Inability in tongue protrusion: Inability in tongue protrusion is also incorrect. This symptom would suggest complete paralysis of the tongue muscles on the affected side, which is not always the case with hypoglossal nerve injury. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the diagnosis for a 24-year-old female patient who presents with fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting for the past 3 days? The patient exhibits neck rigidity and hip and knee flexion upon passive flexion of the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed, and the CSF findings are provided below. Opening pressure – increased Color – cloudy white WBCs – 7000/µl; neutrophil predominant Sugar – 15 mg/dl CSF/serum glucose ratio – 0.2 Protein – 70 mg/dl Latex agglutination – positive Limulus lysate test – negative
questions.explanation: headache, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, and neck rigidity, suggests meningitis. The findings from the CSF analysis also support this diagnosis. The presence of increased opening pressure, cloudy white color, neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis, low CSF/serum glucose ratio, and elevated protein levels are all indicative of meningitis. The positive latex agglutination test and negative Limulus lysate test suggest bacterial etiology. Incorrect Options: Option B - Tubercular meningitis. The positive latex agglutination test is suggestive of tuberculosis, and the presence of neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis is typical of early-stage tubercular meningitis. The low CSF/serum glucose ratio is also a characteristic finding in tubercular meningitis. But it is not the correct option. Option C - Viral meningitis: In viral meningitis, the CSF typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, with normal or slightly elevated protein levels and normal glucose levels. Option D - Fungal meningitis can also present with similar symptoms and CSF findings, including increased opening pressure, low glucose, and elevated protein. However, fungal meningitis is rare and usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.question: Which of the following type of hypersensitivity reactions is seen in myasthenia gravis?
questions.explanation: myasthenia gravis is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction. Hypersensitivity reactions are exaggerated immune responses that can cause tissue damage and disease. Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease, most commonly (80% of cases) caused by antibodies to acetylcholine receptors in the post-junctional membrane of the neuromuscular junction. The autoantibodies in myasthenia gravis are primarily of the IgG subtype and lead to complement-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors. Incorrect Options: Option A - Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction: These reactions typically occur within minutes of exposure and can cause symptoms such as hives, itching, and anaphylaxis. Option C - Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction: Examples of type 3 hypersensitivity reactions include systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis. Option D - Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction: Examples of type 4 hypersensitivity reactions include contact dermatitis and some forms of drug reactions. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of the key clinical features used to diagnose Lewy body dementia?
questions.explanation: refers to a drop in blood pressure upon standing, is not a core clinical feature of LBD. While some individuals with LBD may experience orthostatic hypotension, it is not specific to the diagnosis and can be seen in other neurological or cardiovascular conditions as well. Incorrect Options: Option A - Fluctuating cognition: This is a core clinical feature of Lewy body dementia (LBD). Patients with LBD commonly experience variations in cognitive function, such as fluctuations in attention, alertness, and ability to process information. Option B - Recurrent visual hallucinations: This is a core clinical feature of LBD. Visual hallucinations, often vivid and detailed, are a common symptom in LBD. Option C - REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD): This is a core clinical feature of LBD and considered prodromal symptom. RBD refers to a disturbance during REM sleep where individuals physically act out their dreams, sometimes leading to injury or harm to themselves or their bed partners. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient experiencing repeated inflammation of the optic nerve in both eyes along with widespread inflammation of the spinal cord, and exhibiting visual acuity of 6/60 in the right eye and 6/18 in the left eye, with only a partial response to steroid treatment?

options.B: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.explanation: Devic’s disease, characterized by bilateral optic neuritis and rapidly progresses to blindness. Other clinical characteristics include Area postrema syndrome, Brainstem syndrome, Cerebral syndrome, Diencephalic syndrome, Narcolepsy, and longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis Incorrect options: Option B - Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord: This option is incorrect. Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord is typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to neurological symptoms such as sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, and spasticity. Option C - Posterior cerebral artery stroke: This option is incorrect. Posterior cerebral artery stroke refers to an ischemic stroke affecting the posterior cerebral artery territory of the brain. Option D - Neurosyphilis: This option is incorrect. Neurosyphilis can present with various neurological symptoms, but recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis are not typical features of neurosyphilis.

questions.question: A 40-year-old was brought ro OPD with rapidly progressing dementia and myoclonus. Below is the EEG of the patient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: neurological disorder. The EEG pattern in CJD often shows characteristic findings, including periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) and generalized slowing, which are consistent with the given EEG pattern. Periodic sharp wave complexes are high voltage burst every few seconds, going upward only. Incorrect Options: Option A - The EEG pattern in hepatic encephalopathy typically shows diffuse slowing rather than the specific pattern seen in the given EEG. Option C - Generalized tonic-clonic seizures (also known as grand mal seizures) typically manifest with a EEG pattern characterized by generalized spike and wave discharges during the seizure activity. Option D - The EEG findings in herpes simplex encephalitis may show focal or multifocal abnormalities, such as periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) or focal slowing, which are different from the EEG pattern observed in the given image. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e

questions.question: Which of the following statements about juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is false? Polygenic inheritance Lamotrigine helps in controlling myoclonic jerks Benzodiazepines alone can control myoclonic jerks Valproate should be avoided
questions.explanation: true, while statement 4 is incorrect. Polygenic inheritance: This statement is true. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) is believed to have a polygenic inheritance pattern. Lamotrigine helps in controlling myoclonic jerks: This statement is true. Lamotrigine is effective in controlling myoclonic jerks, which are a characteristic symptom of the condition. Benzodiazepines alone can control myoclonic jerks: This statement is also true. Benzodiazepines, such as clonazepam, are frequently used as a first-line treatment for myoclonic jerks in JME. Incorrect statement Valproate should be avoided: This statement is incorrect. Valproate is used in the treatment of JMS and should be taken lifelong. Reference: .

questions.question: Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis is a complication of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: rare, chronic, progressive and eventually fatal complication of measles, presumably a result of an inability of the nervous system to eradicate the virus. Incorrect options: Option A. Complications of mumps are expressed as inflammation of various organs such as orchitis, oophoritis, encephalitis, pancreatitis, etc. Option C. Complications of rubella include heart problems, loss of hearing and eyesight, intellectual disability, and liver or spleen damage. Option D . The respiratory syncytial virus causes complications of the respiratory tract only. Reference: Prep Ladder, NIND and NIH

questions.question: Identify the lesion shown in the image given below.
questions.explanation: hemangioma. It is usually present at birth and later fades with age. But it does not disappear. A hemangioma is, in fact, a vascular birthmark. Incorrect options: Option B - Melanoma is one of the most severe skin cancer. It is seen as a black-coloured mark on the skin. Option C - Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection where the lesions are present in the form of dome-shaped pearly lesions. Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma is the cancer of the skin's outer and middle layer squamous cells. Reference: Prep Ladder notes and Pediatric Clinical Examination by A.Santhosh Kumar

questions.question: All are true about Brown Sequard Syndrome except
questions.explanation: Syndrome. Ipsilateral Proprioception loss Spastic weakness Development of radicular pain Fasciculation and areflexia Contralateral Pain and temperature loss Incorrect options: Option A, B, and C These are not a feature of Brown-Sequard Syndrome Reference: NIH, Prep Ladder notes and Elsevier

questions.question: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describe tremors? PD is characterized by resting tremor Tremor consist of alternate contraction of agonist and antagonist muscle in an oscillating rhythmic manner Essential tremor is an uncommon movement disorder affecting 5% of the population Normal individuals can have physiologic tremors that manifest as mild high frequency, postural or action tremors
questions.explanation: tremor:Resting tremor is a hallmark feature of Parkinson's disease (PD). Tremor consists of alternate contraction of agonist and antagonist muscles in an oscillating rhythmic manner: Tremors involve rhythmic oscillations of body parts and are typically caused by alternating contractions of agonist and antagonist muscles. Normal individuals can have physiologic tremors that manifest as mild high frequency, postural, or action tremors : Physiologic tremors are normal variations in hand or body tremors that can occur in healthy individuals. They are typically mild and high frequency, occurring during certain postures or actions such as holding a position against gravity or during fine motor tasks. Incorrect statement Essential tremor is an uncommon movement disorder affecting 5% of the population: Essential tremor is actually a common movement disorder, around 5% to 10% of individuals, especially in older age groups. Essential tremor is characterized by postural or action tremors, often involving the hands, head, or voice.

questions.question: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his son. He complains of being unable to move his left arm and leg. According to his son, the patient was reading a book half an hour ago when he realized he couldn't lift his left arm to pick up another book. As he tried to move away from the table, he noticed that his left leg also became very weak. Additionally, he experienced double vision. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His body temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), blood pressure is 165/100 mmHg, pulse is 85 beats/min, and he has a respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min. During the examination, it is observed that the patient has drooping of the right eyelid and his right eye is directed downwards and to the side. When requested to smile, there is a drooping of the left corner of the mouth. The strength of the left upper and lower limbs is rated as 3 out of 5, whereas the strength of the right upper and lower limbs is rated as 5 out of 5. Which region of his brain has experienced ischemia among the following options?
questions.explanation: which is a small, localized ischemic stroke that occurs in the deep structures of the brain. Midbrain, also known as the mesencephalon, is a region of the brainstem that plays a role in coordinating motor movements and controlling eye movements. In this case, the patient's symptoms, including weakness on the left side of the body and abnormal eye movements (ptosis, downward and lateral deviation of the right eye), suggest an ischemic event affecting the midbrain . Incorrect options: Option A - Inner capsule- Damage to the inner capsule can cause motor and sensory deficits. However, in this case, the patient's symptoms are not consistent with an infarct in the inner capsule. Option B - Medulla- While a stroke in the medulla can cause various neurological deficits, the patient's symptoms, such as weakness in the left arm and leg and double vision, are not specific to a medullary infarct. Option D - Occipital lobe- Patient’s visual symptoms of double vision are more likely related to the involvement of the midbrain and its control over eye movements rather than a specific occipital lobe infarct

questions.question: What is the most common cause of Berry aneurysm?

options.A: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
options.B: Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

questions.explanation: vessel is first affected, decreasing the ability of the blood vessels to respond to the tensile shearing stress and making the aneurysm vulnerable to rupture. Incorrect options Option A - is incorrect because while hypertension (HTN) can contribute to the weakening of blood vessels, it is not the primary cause of berry aneurysms. Option C - is incorrect because it mentions an endothelial layer defect, which is not the primary cause of berry aneurysms. Option D - is incorrect because adventitia defect alone is not the primary cause of berry aneurysms. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.explanation: polyradiculopathy causing patchy segmental demyelination of spinal cord and peripheral nerves. Type of paralysisin GBS- Ascending symmetrical paralysis Incorrect options: Option A - Ascending paralysis : GBS typically presents as ascending paralysis. Option C - Plasmapheresis is a treatment method: Plasmapheresis, also known as plasma exchange, is one of the treatment options for GBS. Option D - Demyelinating disorder: GBS is causes patchy segmental demyelination of spinal cord and peripheral nerves. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding patients with trigeminal neuralgia?

options.B: Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve
options.D: No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.explanation: The pain in trigeminal neuralgia is repetitive, severe, and very brief (seconds or less). It may be triggered by touch, a cold wind or eating. Incorrect options: Option A - More common in females: Trigeminal neuralgia is more commonly seen in females, although it can affect both sexes. Option B - Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve: The lancinating pain of trigeminal neuralgia most commonly involves the second and/or third division of trigeminal nerve. Option D - No objective signs of sensory loss : Patients with trigeminal neuralgia do not exhibit objective sensory loss in the affected areas. The pain is usually paroxysmal and does not cause long-term sensory deficits.

questions.question: What is the most frequently observed form of Guillain-Barre syndrome among the options provided?
questions.explanation: demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common subtype of GBS seen mostly in adults. It has motor, sensory, and autonomic involvement. Incorrect options Option A - Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN): This is a subtype of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) characterized by axonal damage to motor nerves. It is less common than AIDP. Option C - Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN ): This is another subtype of GBS characterized by axonal damage to both motor and sensory nerves. It is less common than AIDP. Option D - Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) : This is a variant of GBS characterized by a triad of symptoms: ataxia , ophthalmoplegia , and areflexia . It is less common than AIDP. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the consequence of thrombosis in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery?
questions.explanation: artery (PICA) can cause lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome. Lateral medullary syndrome can occur due to occlusion of any of the 5 vessels Vertebral artery Posterior inferior cerebellar artery Superior medullary artery Middle medullary artery Inferior lateral medullary artery It presents with vertigo, numbness of the ipsilateral face and contralateral limbs, diplopia, hoarseness, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome Incorrect Options: Option B - Weber syndrome: This statement is incorrect. Weber syndrome is caused by the lesions in the midbrain. Option C - Medial medullary syndrome: This statement is incorrect. Medial medullary syndrome is caused by the thrombosis of the anterior spinal artery. Option D - Millard Gubler syndrome: This statement is incorrect. Millard Gubler syndrome, also known as ventral pontine syndrome , is caused by a lesion affecting the pons. Reference: .

questions.question: A 33-year-old female came complains of weakness, easy fatigability, double vision and drooping of the upper eyelids. On examination her deep tendon reflexes are normal. What is the pathogenesis of the condition in this case?

options.A: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
options.D: Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

questions.explanation: symptoms—weakness, easy fatigability, double vision (diplopia), and drooping of the upper eyelids (ptosis)—along with normal deep tendon reflexes, suggest a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis . The pathogenesis of myasthenia gravis involves an autoimmune attack on the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. In myasthenia gravis, autoantibodies target and destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This decreases the efficiency of synaptic transmission, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly after repeated use. Incorrect Options: Option A - Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: This option is incorrect. In myasthenia gravis, the primary defect lies in the postsynaptic membrane of the neuromuscular junction, where autoantibodies target and interfere with AChRs. Option B - Decreased myosin: This option is incorrect. Myosin is a protein involved in muscle contraction. Myasthenia gravis does not involve a decrease in myosin levels or dysfunction of myosin. Option C - Absence of troponin C: This option is incorrect. Troponin C is a component of the regulatory complex involved in muscle contraction. Its absence is not associated with myasthenia gravis. Reference: ..

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Weber's syndrome is incorrect?
questions.explanation: paralysis of the lower face. Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy, or paralysis of the facial muscles on the same side as the brain lesion, such as Bell's palsy or lesions affecting the facial nerve itself. Incorrect Options: Option A - Contralateral hemiplegia: Weber's syndrome, also known as midbrain syndrome, is characterized by the presence of contralateral hemiplegia. Option B - Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy: Weber's syndrome is associated with ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy. Option C - Contralateral parkinsonism: Weber's syndrome is commonly associated with contralateral parkinsonism. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the typical pattern observed in Brown-Sequard syndrome?

options.A: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
options.C: Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.explanation: Brown-Sequard syndrome is contralateral loss of pain sensation. Brown-Sequard syndrome is a neurological condition caused by damage to one half of the spinal cord. Incorrect Options: Option A, C, and D: These options are incorrect Reference: .

questions.question: What medication is employed for mass chemoprophylaxis in the case of meningococcal meningitis?
questions.explanation: against Neisseria meningitidis. It is the drug of choice for mass chemoprophylaxis in individuals who have been in close contact with a person diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Ciprofloxacin is effective in eradicating the bacteria from the nasopharynx, reducing the risk of transmission. Ciprofloxacin is contraindicated in 1 st trimester of pregnancy, hence ceftriaxone is given. Incorrect Options: Option B- Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol can be used for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis, it is not the preferred choice for mass chemoprophylaxis. Option C- Tetracycline: Tetracycline is not the drug of choice for mass chemoprophylaxis.. Option D- Penicillin: Penicillin is effective against many strains of Neisseria meningitidis, but it is not a preferred drug for mass prophylaxis.

questions.question: A 65-year-old, male with hypertension develops sudden onset weakness on the right side of the face & arm. His attender recalls history of headache, blurred vision in the patient which leads to the suspicion of increased ICP. Which is the most common cranial nerve involved in raised ICP?
questions.explanation: affected in cases of increased ICP. When the ICP increases, it can lead to compression or stretching of the abducens nerve, resulting in weakness or paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle. This causes a sign known as false localizing sign, as the problem is due to the stretching of the nerve. Incorrect options: Option B - Trochlear nerve: Increased ICP can potentially affect the trochlear nerve, it is not the most common cranial nerve involved in raised ICP. Therefore, option B is incorrect. Option C - Trigeminal nerve: Increased ICP can cause headache and facial pain, the trigeminal nerve itself is not typically affected as the primary cranial nerve involved in raised ICP. Therefore, option C is incorrect. Option D - Facial nerve: Increased ICP can potentially affect the facial nerve, it is not the most common cranial nerve involved in raised ICP. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the recommended method for preventing meningococcal meningitis during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: meningitis in pregnancy. It is given as a single intramuscular or intravenous dose for prophylaxis in individuals who have had close contact with a person diagnosed with meningococcal disease. Therefore, option A is correct. Incorrect options: Option B - Rifampicin: Rifampicin is also used for the prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis; however, it is not the preferred choice in pregnancy. Therefore, option B is incorrect. Option C - Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is avoided in pregnancy due to potential adverse effects on the developing fetus. Therefore, option C is incorrect. Option D - Penicillin G: Penicillin G is effective against many bacterial infections, but it is not the recommended prophylactic treatment for meningococcal meningitis. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms is absent in Horner syndrome?
questions.explanation: characterized by meiosis (constricted pupil) rather than mydriasis. Incorrect options: Option B, C, D: These symptoms are associated with horner syndrome

questions.question: A 43-year-old patient comes to the OPD with complains tingling sensation in the hands and feet. Reversible dementia is seen in?
questions.explanation: characterized by the degeneration of the spinal cord, peripheral nerves, and sometimes the brain primarily due to Vitamin B12 deficiency. Clinical features include reversible dementia, paresthesias in hand and feet, loss of vibration and position sensation. Treatment includes 1000 microgram of Vitamin B12 IM. Incorrect options: Option B - AD (Alzheimer's Disease): Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by irreversible memory loss, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes. Option C - CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease): Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease leads to rapid neurological decline, including dementia, and unfortunately, it is a fatal condition. CJD is not reversible. Option D - Pick's Disease: Pick's disease, also known as frontotemporal dementia, leads to progressive cognitive decline, personality changes, and behavioral disturbances. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the statements below is NOT accurate regarding Parkinson's disease?

options.B: Usage of Carbidopa leads to on and off phenomenon
options.C: Slight tremor in the hand or foot followed by jaw
options.D: Cog wheel rigidity or lead pipe rigidity is seen

questions.explanation: phenomenon" refers to fluctuations in motor response, where individuals with Parkinson's disease experience periods of improved motor function (on) followed by periods of reduced or absent response to medication (off). This phenomenon is more commonly associated with fluctuations in the effectiveness of levodopa itself, rather than carbidopa. Incorrect Options: Option A - Manganese can cause secondary Parkinsonism: Exposure to high levels of manganese, such as through occupational or environmental sources, can lead to a form of parkinsonism known as manganism. Option C - Slight tremor in the hand or foot followed by jaw: One of the cardinal symptoms of Parkinson's disease is a resting tremor, typically starting in the hand or foot. The tremor can progress to involve other body parts, including the jaw. Option D - Cogwheel rigidity or lead pipe rigidity is seen: Rigidity is a characteristic feature of Parkinson's disease. Cogwheel rigidity refers to a jerky resistance to passive movement characterized by a series of brief interruptions, while lead pipe rigidity refers to a continuous resistance throughout the range of movement. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine. 21st Edition. Pg No 3277

questions.question: As an intern in the neurology ward of the Department of Internal Medicine, you encounter a 48-year-old female patient who has been admitted due to muscle weakness. After conducting investigations and examinations, it is found that her nerve conduction shows a decremental response , but she displays signs of flaccidity. Based on these findings, what possible diagnosis would you consider?
questions.explanation: studies and a flaccid weakness pattern. In myasthenia gravis, weakness often worsens with exertion and improves with rest. Repetitive nerve stimulation test may show decremental response if the muscle is affected (>10% decrease at the frequency of 3 Hz stimulation) Incorrect options: Option B - (GBS - Guillain-Barré syndrome) is incorrect because GBS is characterized by reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and can show abnormalities in nerve conduction studies. Option C - (Transverse myelitis) is incorrect because transverse myelitis is typically associated with abnormalities in nerve conduction studies and may present with spastic weakness rather than flaccid weakness. Option D - (Traumatic neuritis) is incorrect because traumatic neuritis would not typically present with flaccid weakness and normal nerve conduction studies.

questions.question: Extensor Reflex on pinching gastrocnemius muscle is called?
questions.explanation: known as the Gordon sign. It is an abnormal reflex response where pinching the gastrocnemius muscle leads to extension of the big toe instead of the normal flexion response. The Gordon sign can be seen in upper motor neuron lesions, such as in pyramidal tract dysfunction. Incorrect options: Option A - (Gower Sign) is incorrect because the Gower sign is associated with Duchenne muscular dystrophy and refers to the characteristic way that individuals with muscle weakness in the lower extremities rise from a squatting or sitting position. They use their hands to "walk" up their legs and push themselves into a standing position. Option B - (Homan Sign) is incorrect because the Homan sign is a clinical finding associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the lower extremities. It is characterized by pain in the calf upon passive dorsiflexion of the foot. Option C - (Oppenheim Sign) is incorrect because the Oppenheim sign is a test used to assess upper motor neuron dysfunction. It involves applying firm pressure along the anterior tibial surface from the knee to the ankle, and a positive sign is indicated by a downward movement of the big toe.

questions.question: Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: abnormal myelination of the central nervous system. The tigroid white matter appearance on MR imaging is a classic finding in this condition due to alternating areas of myelination and demyelination Incorrect Option: Option A: Pantothenate kinase deficiency is a rare neurodegenerative disorder characterized by impaired synthesis of coenzyme A (CoA). It is not specifically associated with a tigroid white matter pattern on MR imaging. Option C: Neuroferritinopathy is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder characterized by abnormal iron deposition in the brain. It typically does not present with a tigroid white matter pattern on MR imaging. Option D: Aceruloplasminemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the absence or dysfunction of ceruloplasmin, leading to abnormal iron metabolism. It is not specifically associated with a tigroid white matter pattern on MR imaging. Reference: .

questions.question: A 52-year-old man was brought to the OPD with complaints of multiple hyperpigmented skin macules which started in his childhood. These fibromas near the eyelid have increased in size causing visual disturbance. Identify the disease shown in the below image.
questions.explanation: neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder characterized by the development of neurofibromas, which are benign tumors arising from nerve tissue. Plexiform neurofibromas involve multiple nerves and can cause disfigurement and functional impairments. Incorrect Options: Option A - Facial nerve palsy: Facial nerve palsy refers to the weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by the facial nerve. Option C - Masticator space abscess: Masticator space abscess refers to an abscess (collection of pus) within the masticator space, which is an anatomical region containing the muscles of mastication (chewing). Option D - Fibrous dysplasia: Fibrous dysplasia is a bone disorder characterized by the abnormal development of fibrous tissue within the bone, leading to weakening and deformity.

questions.question: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with sudden onset difficulty in micturition and defaecation. There was no history of a cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: characterized by the compression of the cauda equina nerve roots in the lower spinal canal. Clinical features of cauda equina syndrome: Difficulty with micturition Loss of anal sphincter tone or fecal incontinence Saddle anesthesia Gait disturbance Pain, numbness or weakness affecting one or both legs. Incorrect Option : Option A - Pott's Spine: Pott's Spine, also known as spinal tuberculosis, typically presents with chronic back pain, deformity, and constitutional symptoms such as weight loss and fever. Option B - Guillain-Barré Syndrome: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is an autoimmune condition characterized by ascending muscle weakness, usually starting in the legs and progressing upwards. Option D - Multiple Sclerosis: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) presents with a wide range of neurological symptoms, including muscle weakness, sensory changes, and coordination problems. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT appears normal. What would be your next step?
questions.explanation: weakness in a patient with high blood pressure suggests a possible ischemic stroke involving the territory of the middle cerebral artery. Thrmobloysis is the preferred treatment in this patient as there is no hemorrhagic stroke. Window period for thrombolysis is <4.5 hours of symptoms onset. Thrombolysis can be done up to 6 hours of symptom onset. Option Options : Option A - Nothing , since CT was normal: While the CT scan may not show any immediate abnormalities, it does not rule out an acute ischemic stroke. Option B - Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel is commonly used for the prevention of recurrent strokes in patients with ischemic stroke of atherosclerotic origin. Option D - Advice BP control: Blood pressure control is an essential aspect of managing acute ischemic stroke, but in this scenario, the immediate concern is the potential for thrombolysis. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e

questions.question: A patient walks with a stomping gait. When asked to close his eyes and walk, he is unable to do so. Which of the following tracts is probably affected?
questions.explanation: typically due to loss of proprioception, which is the sense of the relative position of one's own body parts. Proprioception is mainly carried by the posterior column (dorsal column) of the spinal cord. Function: The posterior column tract (or dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway) carries proprioceptive information, vibration sense, and fine touch. Damage to this tract results in loss of proprioception, causing a stomping gait as the patient relies on visual cues to know the position of their legs. When eyes are closed, the patient loses these cues, resulting in difficulty walking. Incorrect Options : Option A - Spinocerebellar tract Function: Carries unconscious proprioceptive information to the cerebellum to help coordinate movements. Damage to this tract results in ataxia, but it is usually characterized by uncoordinated movements rather than a stomping gait. The patient might not show increased difficulty with eyes closed compared to eyes open. Option C - Vestibulospinal tract Function: Involved in maintaining balance and posture by controlling the muscles of the trunk and limbs. Damage to this tract would result in balance issues, but the patient would not typically present with a stomping gait or show significant worsening with eyes closed. Option D - Rubrospinal tract Function: Involved in the fine control of limb movements, particularly the flexors. Reasoning: Lesions in this tract are rare and typically do not cause a stomping gait or the described difficulty in walking with eyes closed. They might cause more subtle motor deficits. Reference: .

questions.question: In the sagittal section of the brain given below, if the coloured area is affected, which of the following is not seen?
questions.explanation: represents a lesion in the area of the cerebral cortex known as the precentral gyrus or primary motor cortex. This region is responsible for motor control and coordination. Perianal anesthesia: Perianal anesthesia refers to the loss of sensation around the anus. The precentral gyrus, which is primarily involved in motor function, is not directly responsible for sensory perception. Sensory information, including perianal sensation, is processed in the somatosensory cortex, which is located in the postcentral gyrus. Incorrect Options: Option A - Urinary incontinence: The precentral gyrus is involved in the control of voluntary movement, including the coordination of the muscles involved in urinary continence. Damage to this area can disrupt the normal control of urinary function, leading to urinary incontinence. Option B - Gait apraxia: The precentral gyrus is crucial for the initiation and coordination of voluntary movements, including walking. Therefore, damage to this area can result in gait apraxia. Option D - Fecal incontinence: The precentral gyrus is involved in the coordination of the muscles involved in maintaining bowel continence. Damage to this area can disrupt the normal control of bowel function, leading to fecal incontinence. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e

questions.question: A 16-year-old girl, who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would your advice be?

options.A: Stop the treatment and follow up
options.B: Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment

questions.explanation: withdrawal: Complete medical control of seizures for 1-5 years. Single seizure type, with generalized seizures having a better prognosis that focal seizures. Normal neurologic examination, including intelligence No family history of epilepsy Normal EEG. The treatment needs to be continued for 2 years as the risk of seizure recurrence after a seizure free period is highest within first 2 years. Incorrect options: Option A - Stop the treatment and follow up: Stopping the treatment abruptly in a patient with a history of epilepsy, even after a seizure-free period, carries a risk of seizure recurrence. Option B - Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: Tapering and stopping the drug immediately after a 6-month seizure-free period may increase the risk of seizure recurrence. Option D - Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: Lifelong treatment with AEDs is not necessary in all cases of epilepsy. Reference: .
